awd_titl_txt: Magnitude, Extent, and Impact of a Pre-Historical Multi-Century Drought in the Western US
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project will investigate the causes of a multi-century drought in western North America during the Late Holocene Dry Period and will analyze its geographic extent and impact on Native Americans living in the immediate area.  Droughts are a regular feature of climatic conditions in the western U.S., and global prediction models suggest that they will intensify in the future.  Drought impacts society through agricultural losses, water restrictions, and a range of other damages to businesses, utilities, and industry.  By analyzing paleoclimatic patterns, this project will enhance basic understanding of the ocean-atmosphere dynamics that create persistent droughts in the western United States.  The project will provide new insights into strategies employed by prehistoric populations to cope with these harsh environmental changes.  Given the devastating social, economic, and ecological impacts of droughts, this project will provide rich insights regarding drought dynamics and responses to drought.  The project also will provide education and training opportunities for Native American undergraduate and graduate students through laboratory research experiences and fieldwork on tribal lands.

In the western U.S., precipitation patterns during the Late Holocene Dry Period had a persistent dipolar pattern of a dry southwest and a wet northwest, similar to the pattern produced during the modern-day La Nina phases of the El Nino Southern Oscillation.  Because of these similarities, the paleoclimatic record for the Late Holocene Dry Period offers insights into the temperature and precipitation profiles that caused long-duration, high-intensity droughts in the region.  This project will focus on three core questions:  (1) What were the spatial and temporal extents of the atmospheric circulation patterns that resulted in the dipolar conditions of very long-term drought in the southwest and wet climate in the northwest?  (2) What was the precipitation and temperature regime during the Late Holocene Dry Period?   (3) What was the nature and extent of human response to an extended period of environmental change?  The investigators will analyze pollen from sediment cores collected from wet meadows along a north-south transect in Nevada and Idaho to reconstruct temporal changes in precipitation.  Carbon and oxygen isotopes will be analyzed from remnant sagebrush wood to reconstruct seasonal patterns of precipitation and temperature.  Curated collections from key archaeological sites will be re-dated using high-resolution accelerator mass spectrometry radiocarbon to identify small, short-lived organics for reconstructing the responses of Native American populations to periods of intense drought.  Findings from this research will enhance capabilities to model future megadroughts and persistent drought conditions.

por.por_cntn:
This project studied the timing and geographic extent of a major drought in the Great Basin of Nevada that persisted for over 1000 years, termed the Late Holocene Dry Period (LHDP). We examined pollen of grasses and sedges preserved in sediments recovered from four wet meadows in valleys across a longitudinal transect in Nevada spanning from the center of the state (39 degrees latitude) to near the Oregon border (42 degrees latitude).

We found that beginning about 3100 years ago, these wet sedge meadows dried and became dry grass meadows. This persisted until 2200 years ago when precipitation returned to normal and the meadows once again filled with water. The wet phase lasted 200 years and then across the Great Basin a severe drought period began and lasted another 200 years (between 2000 and 1800 years ago). Major lakes across the region were at their lowest elevation during this period, and trees in nearby mountain ranges had very slow rates of growth. After ~1800 years ago the precipitation again increased, lake levels rose and valley bottoms returned to being wet meadows. The period between 2000 and 1800 years ago now appears to be the driest recorded in the west within the last 4000 years.

The pattern of this drought conforms to what is called a dipole, with wet climate persisting to the north and dry climate to the south. The hinge point is about 40 degrees north latitude in central Nevada, but varies with the intensity of drought. From 3100 to 2200 years ago, the jet stream must have been anchored north of 40 degrees latitude, bringing wetter conditions to areas north of this, but drought in areas to the south. About 2000 years ago, the jet stream shifted south of 39 degrees, bringing wet climate to central Nevada for two centuries. Then, the jet stream must have shifted abruptly north of 41 degrees latitude bringing extreme drought to all of central and western Nevada for two centuries. After 1800 the jet stream again shifted south once again bringing wetter climate to central Nevada. Throughout this period, the jet stream has a somewhat sinuous pattern, curving north over western Nevada, swinging south in central Nevada and then flowing back north as it moves across the Great Basin towards Utah.

We also reconstructed potential changes to human habitation in the Great Basin by intensively redating plant materials in museum collections collected during previous archaeological excavations. Newer methods of radiocarbon dating, using accelerator mass spectrometry (AMS 14C) allow us to date tiny amounts of carbon which were impossible to date using previous techniques. Modeling of the new intensively dated sites show that sites south of 39 degrees were abandoned during the long dry phase of the LHDP (3100 to 2200 years ago), reoccupied during the wet phase (2200 to 2000 years ago) and once again abandoned during the extreme drought (2000 to 1800 years ago). Sites north of 40 degrees latitude where climate was wetter remained occupied for much of the early LHDP (3100 to 2500 years ago) but then abandoned when the early dry phase became more extreme. These northern sites were also reoccupied during the wet phase (2200 to 2000 years ago) but then abandoned during the period of most extreme drought (2000 to 1800 years ago).  These results show that climate change was sufficiently severe to disrupt the lifeways of Native Americans and force relocation during extreme drought.

In the face of potential future climate change, our results demonstrate that past climate change created droughts that persisted for centuries and were disruptive to local populations. While modern societies have more tools for coping with climate change, water stress associated with repeated droughts in recent decades has put many communities in the western United States in jeopardy. Persistent drought has an immediate effect on urban and agricultural regions dependent on scarce water supplies. Drought in the west today has a disproportionate impact on rural Native American populations which highlights issues of environmental justice in the context of climate change. Knowing that widespread drought lasted multiple centuries in the past should alert us to planning for potential long-term water scarcity in the future, and inequities in water distribution.

 This project supported four Native American undergraduate students from tribal communities in the west with summer research opportunities. The project supported three graduate students and resulted in one Master's of Science degree. It also supported one post-doctoral scholar.
